trigger: User edits to Lessons Learned 2026 post (lessons 17-20) after voice-polish + ai-pattern-killer pipeline
source: Direct comparison of pipeline output vs user's manual edits

banned_structures_added.reason: User cut 'The code compiles. The tests pass. But...' and 'The code compiles. The feature works. But...' in every occurrence. Short-declarative stacking before a But pivot is manufactured drama.
User cut explanation paragraphs that restated what the story already showed. In lesson 17, the FK anecdote carried the argument alone — two paragraphs of explanation were redundant.
User changed '2AM page' to 'headache', 'security slop' to 'security gaps', removed 'the system rots'. Prefers neutral precise words over stylistic ones.

banned_structures_added.pattern: Generic advice over specific tool references
banned_structures_added.reason: User replaced 'Keep your prompt engineering in files you can version and test' with 'Have identical AGENTS, GEMINI, and CLAUDE.md files.' Wants the specific implementation, not the principle.
User added '(though it's helpful because your gut is telling you something)' to a clean feelings-vs-taste binary. The dismissed side had partial value that needed acknowledging.

rewriting_strategies_added: 27. Name the tool, not the principle

summary: Five new structural patterns and five new rewriting strategies added based on systematic analysis of user edits to four lessons. Core theme: the user prefers tighter, plainer prose that trusts the reader and names specific tools. AI pipeline over-dramatizes, over-explains, and reaches for color when plain precision communicates faster.

trigger: Audit of ai-pattern-killer against softaworks/agent-toolkit humanizer skill (based on Wikipedia WikiProject AI Cleanup patterns)

banned_phrases_added.reason: Wordy filler — 5 words where 'because' works. From humanizer's filler replacement pairs.
Bureaucratic filler for 'now'. From humanizer's filler replacement pairs.
Wordy conditional — 'if' does the same job. From humanizer's filler replacement pairs.
Nominalized filler for 'can'. From humanizer's filler replacement pairs.
Filler preposition — 'to' does the same job. From humanizer's filler replacement pairs.
Vague attribution — name the source or drop the claim. From humanizer's weasel words category.
Phantom attribution. From humanizer's weasel words category.
Vague attribution hiding behind anonymous critics. From humanizer's weasel words category.
Vague attribution with fake plurality. From humanizer's weasel words category.
Generic optimistic closer with zero specifics. From humanizer's generic positive conclusions category.
Generic optimistic closer. From humanizer's generic positive conclusions category.
Motivational-poster language as closing. From humanizer's generic positive conclusions category.
Generic optimistic transition. From humanizer's generic positive conclusions category.

banned_phrases_added.phrase: A major step in the right direction
banned_phrases_added.reason: Politician-press-statement closer. From humanizer's generic positive conclusions category.
Sycophantic chatbot opener. From humanizer's collaborative communication artifacts category.
Sycophantic chatbot opener. From humanizer's collaborative communication artifacts category.
Sycophantic chatbot stalling. From humanizer's sycophantic tone category.

banned_structures_added.reason: AI bolds phrases at regular intervals across paragraphs. Humans bold sparingly. From humanizer's overuse of boldface category.
3+ -ing analysis phrases in one paragraph signals AI packing in pseudo-analytical filler. From humanizer's superficial analyses with -ing endings category.

summary: 18 new banned phrases and 2 new banned structures added after cross-referencing with the softaworks humanizer skill (based on Wikipedia's WikiProject AI Cleanup patterns). Filled gaps in: wordy filler replacements (5), vague attribution weasel words (4), generic optimistic conclusions (5), sycophantic chatbot openers (3), mechanical boldface emphasis (1), and present participle density as a structural pattern (1). No changes to rewriting strategies or scoring — existing pipeline handles these new patterns without modification.

trigger: Running ai-pattern-killer on Context Engineering blog post revealed the pipeline was mechanically rewriting deliberate rhetorical choices (negation-reframes, three-part parallels) with no judgment layer
source: Live pipeline run + user feedback on output quality

pipeline_changes.change: Added REQUIRED/REVIEW tier system to flag classification
pipeline_changes.reason: Structural patterns like negation-reframes and three-part parallels can be either AI defaults or deliberate rhetoric. The pipeline was treating all pattern matches as equally suspect, destroying effective writing while fixing AI tells.

pipeline_changes.change: REQUIRED tier: auto-applied by rewriter (banned words, phrases, formatting conventions, rhythm failures)
pipeline_changes.reason: These patterns are almost never intentional — filler, jargon, chatbot artifacts, formatting issues.

pipeline_changes.change: REVIEW tier: presented as suggestions with rationale, user accepts/rejects (parallels, negation-reframes, dramatic buildup, escalation, binary dismissals)
pipeline_changes.reason: These patterns involve sentence/paragraph-level rhetoric where the same construction can be an AI default or effective writing.

pipeline_changes.change: Escalation rule: REVIEW patterns appearing 3+ times in same piece escalate to REQUIRED on third instance
pipeline_changes.reason: One negation-reframe is likely voice. Four is likely an AI default. Frequency is a signal.

pipeline_changes.change: Scorer no longer penalizes REVIEW patterns left in place
pipeline_changes.reason: If the user retains a REVIEW pattern, it shouldn't drag down the humanization score.

summary: Added REQUIRED/REVIEW tier system across all three agents. REQUIRED flags (words, phrases, formatting, rhythm) are auto-applied. REVIEW flags (rhetorical structures like parallels, negation-reframes, dramatic buildup) are presented as suggestions with rationale for user accept/reject. Escalation rule promotes REVIEW to REQUIRED when the same pattern appears 3+ times. Scorer respects tiers — retained REVIEW patterns don't reduce scores. Core insight: the pipeline was optimizing for pattern removal when it should have been optimizing for pattern judgment.
